subject: Google Summer of Code 2019 - deadline is today!
header: Before you do anything else this week, check out the announcement of TPF about the Google Summer of code.
It says the dead-line is February 4, 2019. which is today. (The GSOC site mentions February 6, 2019., but TPF might need to have some time to put everything together. So go ahead, check it out now!
Then come back, go on reading the newsletter and enjoy your week!

entries.title: Vienna.pm TechMeet
entries.author: thomas_klausner
entries.text: What can I say. While many other Perl Monger groups have shut down, the Viennese plan their meeting a year ahead. Including the one when they have grilled camel. I am impressed.

entries.title: Google Summer of Code 2019
entries.author: makoto_nozaki
entries.text: The Perl Foundation is participating in Google Summer of Code again this year. Deadline is today!

entries.title: Full Text Search for ebooks
entries.author: frew_schmidt
entries.url: Free took all of his eBooks, converted them to plain text files using Calibre, then loaded the text into an SQLite database in just 7 seconds and voila. He has a full-text search of all of his books.

entries.title: Exploring Type::Tiny Part 7: Creating a Type Library with Type::Library
entries.author: toby_inkster

entries.title: Monthly Report - January
entries.author: mohammad_anwar
entries.text: Once, a long time ago I also wrote similar activity reports, but I think I only did 2 or maybe 3 of them. Seeing how Mohammed stick to these, I wonder if I should start them again. Would this publication help me doing things better or would it just make me nerveous that I have to report to the open Internet that I have failed in some of my plans? Have you tried to follow the footsteps of Mohammad?

entries.title: Bugs!? - static analysis to the rescue
entries.author: jonas_nielsen
entries.text: A few weeks ago Dave Cross wrote about a subtle bug. Now Jonas adds a Perl::Critic policy that together with a CI tool will be able to help you keep the bug out of your code.

entries.title: I'm not positive about this...
entries.author: bob
entries.text: How the unary minus operator on strings can make you questions your life choices.

entries.title: Surprising output for the descending range '01'..'-1'
entries.author: brian_d_foy
entries.text: Because of the flexibility of Perl and the automatic type conversion the range operator has some edge-cases that are probabaly unintended and might go away. brian d foy shows them to us.

chapters.title: Perl Tutorial
chapters.header: A section for newbies and for people who need some refreshing of their Perl knowledge. If you have questions or suggestions about the articles, let me know and I'll try to make the necessary changes. The included articles are from the Perl Maven Tutorial and are part of the Perl Maven eBook.

entries.title: Deploying to Kubernetes at ZipRecruiter
entries.author: frew_schmidt
entries.text: Describing a bunch of tools created at ZR and the process for getting an app deployed. There is nothing Perl-specific in this, but it can be very much relevant to anyone doing DevOps related tasks.

entries.text: It is a bit late to report this now, but this is how the scheduling happened. In any case, thanks for maintaining the Perl presence at FOSDEM every year!
